awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Novel Statistical Data Analysis Approaches for Mining Human Genetics Datasets
awd_abstract_narration:
The advent of modern genotyping and sequencing technologies has revolutionized human genetics research, allowing researchers to truly understand how different we are from one another. Large datasets describing the common patterns of human genetic variation may be easily thought of as matrices, with the rows representing individuals and the columns representing loci in the genome that correspond to common polymorphisms. The broader impact of such datasets cannot be overemphasized: they are a key resource for researchers to use to find genes affecting health, disease, and responses to drugs and environmental factors, as well as understanding the evolutionary and biological history of our species. Extracting useful information from such datasets promotes the progress of science and, at the same time, advances national health, prosperity and welfare. This project will bridge the gap between state-of-the-art algorithms for data analysis developed in the theoretical computer science and applied mathematics communities and the application of such algorithms to the analysis of the increasingly larger volume of datasets in the human genetics community.

In the context of this project, first, from an algorithmic perspective, the project team will design and analyze novel algorithms for three prototypical, fundamental research topics that combine linear algebra and randomization, namely sparse Principal Components Analysis, matrix completion, and linear (or kernel) discriminant analysis. All three topics have been widely popular in the theoretical computer science, machine learning, and applied mathematics communities. Yet these research topics have been essentially overlooked by the population genetics community. Second, from a population genetics perspective, the team will apply the developed algorithms to gain novel insights regarding population structure, ancestry informative markers, and natural selection, as well as improve imputation methods and Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) data analysis. All three methods will be evaluated on population genetics datasets that are available to the PIs. The project will train graduate students and will disseminate the results of the research to a broad community of applied mathematicians, theoretical computer scientists, and population geneticists.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The advent of modern genotyping and sequencing technologies has revolutionized human genetics research, allowing researchers to truly understand how different we are from one another. Large datasets describing the common patterns of human genetic variation may be easily thought of as matrices, with the rows representing individuals and the columns representing loci in the genome that correspond to common polymorphisms. The broader impact of such datasets cannot be overemphasized: they are a key resource for researchers to use to find genes affecting health, disease, and responses to drugs and environmental factors, as well as understanding the evolutionary and biological history of our species.


Our project contributed numerous discoveries to help bridge the gap between state-of-the-art algorithms in theoretical computer science and applied mathematics with the analysis of large-scale human genetics datasets. This interdisciplinary effort leveraged algorithmic techniques to gain novel insights into population genetics, ranging from ancestry and natural selection to disease associations. The project also contributed to the training of graduate students and disseminated research findings to a broad community of researchers. More precisely, our project achieved several significant outcomes:

1. Algorithmic Innovations: Novel algorithms were developed and analyzed for feature selection in Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) and informative feature identification in Principal Components Analysis (PCA). These algorithms offer improved interpretability and scalability.

2. Imputation Techniques: Algorithms for imputation in large-scale genotypic datasets were created, facilitating the filling of missing entries in large-scale genomic matrices. 

3. Tera-Scale Data Handling: Algorithms for processing tera-scale genomic datasets were designed and implemented, addressing the growing scale of genomic datasets.

4. Population Genetics Insights: The project applied the developed algorithms to population genetics datasets, providing new insights into population structure, ancestry informative markers, and natural selection.

5. Disease Associations: Genomic data from Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) were analyzed, leading to the identification of genetic markers, genes, and pathways potentially implicated in the etiology of common disorders.

The project resulted in the publication of 16 research papers in leading conferences and journals, contributing to the scientific community's knowledge in human genetics and computational biology. This project successfully brought together algorithmic innovations from computer science and mathematics with the field of human genetics. The project also helped trained three students who graduated with PhD degrees from Purdue University, co-advised by the project co-PIs. 


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Petros Drineas
